items.title: In China, a Vast Chasm Between the Rich and the Rest
items.abstract: The gulf between China’s booming cities and its poor countryside has become a major source of social unrest.

items.title: Bloomberg Outlines $20 Billion Storm Protection Plan
items.abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled a far-reaching proposal that included building a network of barriers, fortifying the power grid and retrofitting older buildings.

items.title: Geography, Not Voting Rights Act, Accounts for Most Majority-Minority Districts
items.abstract: There has been a lot of speculation about how the Supreme Court’s decision on the Voting Rights Act might affect the partisan composition of Congress, but most of it gets the story wrong.

items.title: In Climbing Income Ladder, Location Matters
items.abstract: The odds of rising to another income level are notably low in certain cities, like Atlanta and Charlotte, and much higher in New York and Boston.

items.title: In Lieu of Money, Toyota Donates Efficiency to New York Charity
items.abstract: Toyota engineers brought kaizen, a Japanese word meaning “continuous improvement,” to the Food Bank for New York City, cutting wait times at soup kitchens and streamlining procedures.
keywords: Food Bank for New York City

items.title: New York City
items.abstract: New books include Gerard Koeppel’s “City on a Grid: How New York Became New York.”
keywords: City on a Grid: How New York Became New York (Book)
Fun City: John Lindsay, Joe Namath, and How Sports Saved New York in the 1960s (Book)
The Con Men: Hustling in New York City (Book)

items.title: Review: In ‘City of Thorns,’ Ben Rawlence Tells a Refugee Camp’s Story
items.abstract: In this book, Mr. Rawlence spotlights nine people to describe life in a Kenyan refugee camp he calls the biggest in the world.
keywords: City of Thorns: Nine Lives in the World's Largest Refugee Camp (Book)

items.title: Michigan’s Failure to Protect Flint
items.abstract: The state, which had played down findings of high levels of lead in the city’s water, must step in to find solutions.

items.title: New York City Rejects Federal Findings That Many Elementary Schools Defy Disabilities Law
items.abstract: The de Blasio administration took issue with a report saying that the majority of city elementary schools are not fully accessible to disabled people.

items.title: A Bruised San Bernardino Shows Cultural Stirrings
items.abstract: A poet and a photographer, both professors, are helping to lead efforts to reinvigorate and redefine the city through the arts.

items.title: A Growing Chorus of Big City Prosecutors Say No to Marijuana Convictions
items.abstract: Marlyn Mosby, Baltimore’s top prosecutor, says she will no longer prosecute marijuana possession cases and will vacate thousands of convictions. The police disagree.

items.title: Amazon Pulls Out of Planned New York City Headquarters
items.abstract: Its plan to build a sprawling complex in Queens in return for nearly for $3 billion in government incentives had come under fierce opposition from local lawmakers.

items.title: Homes Lost and Lives Trampled, Rural Afghans Urgently Want Peace
items.abstract: Desperate for any sort of truce, many of those displaced by fighting already lack the basic rights that urban elites fear will be lost in a deal with the Taliban.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: The Pizza-and-Beer Train: New York City’s Hidden Railroad
items.abstract: Most New Yorkers have not heard of the New York & Atlantic Railway, a freight line in the middle of New York City. But the line is growing, as rail freight emerges as a viable option.

items.title: Is New York City’s ‘Remarkable Growth Story’ Ending?
items.abstract: City planning officials dispute the latest census figures, which suggest that New York’s post-recession growth has finally slowed.

items.title: New Virus Cases Begin to Slow in U.S. Cities Where Omicron Hit First
items.abstract: Reports of infections are falling in Cleveland, Newark and Washington, suggesting that a national peak may be approaching.

items.title: City Harvest Moves Into an Expansive Space in Sunset Park, Brooklyn
items.abstract: Sushi, sashimi and steaks from a Las Vegas presence, a financial district outpost for Blue Ribbon Sushi Bar & Grill, and more restaurant news.

items.title: Far From the Big City, New Economic Life
items.abstract: Incomes are low in small-town Tennessee, but so is the cost of living. That attraction could be a key to reviving many rural areas.

items.title: Companies Finalize $26 Billion Deal With States and Cities to End Opioid Lawsuits
items.abstract: The first checks could be cut in April. The money — from the nation’s three major pharmaceutical distributors and Johnson & Johnson — will be used for addiction treatment and prevention.

items.title: New York City’s schools chancellor is lifting an outdoor mask mandate.
items.abstract: Masking inside the city’s public schools will still be required, as is the case across the state, but not outside on school grounds.
